title.value: Asymmetry in the Complexity of the Multi-Commodity Network Pricing Problem
title.justification: The title is explicitly mentioned at the beginning of the paper as well as in the metadata section.
title.quote: Asymmetry in the Complexity of the Multi-Commodity Network Pricing Problem

extractions.description: This paper explores the complexity of the Multi-Commodity Network Pricing Problem (NPP), a bilevel optimization problem involving network pricing and shortest path determination. It investigates the problem's complexity depending on the number of tolled arcs and commodities and introduces an algorithm to solve the NPP in polynomial time under certain conditions. The study also introduces the concepts of strong bilevel feasibility and uses convex conjugate to formulate the NPP's complexity, offering practical algorithms and demonstrating their efficacy through numerical experiments.

type.justification: The paper focuses on the theoretical complexity of the Network Pricing Problem and introduces concepts like strong bilevel feasibility and novel algorithms while also leveraging mathematical concepts like convex conjugate.
type.quote: In this paper, we prove that the number of commodities |K| and the number of tolled arcs |A1 | scale the NPP differently.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on optimizing network pricing strategies, particularly at a theoretical level.
name.quote: The network pricing problem (NPP) is a bilevel problem, where the leader optimizes its revenue by deciding on the prices of certain arcs in a graph.

name.justification: The paper involves strategies and models that are essential to the field of Operations Research, including bilevel programming and algorithm design for network problems.

name.justification: The paper introduces and proves new algorithms and examines their computational complexity, which is a key aspect of algorithm theory.
name.quote: We devise a simple algorithm showing that if the number of tolled arcs is fixed, then the problem can be solved in polynomial time with respect to the number of commodities.
